content:
A curved back and tapered legs are great distinguishing features to start with. That sounds like a very stylish and elegant design.

Several mid-century modern designers were known for incorporating curved lines and tapered legs into their work. Here are a few possibilities that come to mind:

1. Eero Saarinen: Saarinen's designs often featured curved, organic shapes, and his chairs often had tapered legs. His famous "Womb Chair" (1948) has a curved back and tapered legs, but it's a bit more rounded and bulky than what you described.
2. Charles Eames: Eames' chairs often featured a curved back and tapered legs, especially his earlier designs. The Eames Lounge Chair (1956) comes to mind, but it has a more pronounced ottoman and a slightly different shape than what you described.
3. Milo Baughman: Baughman was an American designer who worked in a variety of styles, but he did create some chairs with curved backs and tapered legs. His designs often featured sleek, low-profile silhouettes, so it's possible he might have created a chair that fits your description.
4. Edward Wormley: Wormley was another American designer who worked in the mid-century modern style. He created several chairs with curved backs and tapered legs, often featuring a more subtle, understated aesthetic.

These are just a few possibilities, but there were many other designers working in this style during the mid-century modern era. If you remember any other details about the chair you saw in the magazine, such as the material, color, or any distinctive features, it might help narrow down the search.

Sorry to hear you didn't win the antique clock at the auction, but it's great that you and your cousin had a fun experience! Auctions can be exciting, and it's always a thrill to find a unique piece. I hope you'll find the perfect armchair to match your grandmother's Victorian-era chest.

Do you think you might be able to find the magazine or take a photo of the chair you saw, so I can get a better sense of the design?
